Award.AwardTitle: Analytic Number Theory and its Applications, July 14-18, 2014
Award.AbstractNarration:
In the last thirty years there have been two dramatic breakthroughs in analytic number theory: the use of automorphic forms on higher rank groups, and the introduction of multiple Dirichlet series. A conference focusing on recent advances around these two breakthroughs will be held at Perrotis College, Thessaloniki, Greece, July 14-18, 2014. The conference will feature lectures by twenty leaders in the field. One of the main aims of this conference is to introduce young researchers to this exciting new frontier by suggesting open problems and new research directions. This award supports the participation of US-based postdocs, graduate students, and researchers without other sources of support.

The conference "Analytic Number Theory and its Applications" is centered on research by Jeff Hoffstein and his collaborators and students. Topics to be discussed include the construction of Weyl group multiple Dirichlet series associated to any finite or affine reduced root system, convexity breaking, non vanishing results of L-functions, the description of Fourier-Whittaker coefficients of metaplectic Eisenstein series in terms of crystal graphs, asymptotics of integral moments of L-functions, and surprising relationships between theta functions and multiple Dirichlet series. The meeting provides an international audience with opportunities for cross-pollination of ideas between classical problems in analytic number theory and recent breakthroughs in automorphic forms and multiple Dirichlet series.

Conference website: http://math.umn.edu/~brubaker/jh2014c.html

POR.DRECONTENT:
The grant supported the conference: “Analytic number theory and its applications'' which was held at Perrotis College, Thessaloniki, Greece, July 14 - 18, 2014. Funds were used to cover travel costs as well as room and board.  Four graduate students, six postdocs, as well as a few of the speakers were supported by the NSF grant. Additional funding was provided by the Clay Mathematics Foundation as well as the Foundation Compositio Mathematica. The organizers were Ben Brubaker (University of Minnesota) , Nikolaos Diamantis (Nottingham University),  and Dorian Goldfeld (Columbia University).

Analytic number theory can be defined as the study of numbers using
methods from mathematical analysis. Important  advances in analytic number theory include the theory of multiple Dirirchlet series, the study of automorphic forms  on high rank groups, sieve methods, and work on moments of L-functions. The Thessaloniki conference provided an opportunity to bring together experts and younger researchers who work in analytic number theory to make further  progress in the field with an aim towards applications. Very recent achievements highlighted at the conference included the construction of Weyl group multiple Dirichlet series associated to any finite or affine reduced root system,  convexity breaking and vanishing results for L-functions and their averages, the description of Fourier-Whittaker coefficients of metaplectic Eisenstein series in terms of crystal graphs and statistical mechanical models, asymptotics of integral moments of L-functions, and surprising relations between theta functions and multiple Dirichlet series.

 

 Several of the talks at the conference were of a more expository nature opeoning the field for those not directly working in these areas. Besides high level talks, there were also problem sessions devoted to presenting research problems that people could work on. The conference was an important milestone for putting into global perspective the most recent breakthroughs in the field.
